byline.original: Susan Heller Anderson and Maurice Carroll

results.lead_paragraph: Space and 'Sesame Street' ''How high does a satellite go?'' asked Maria of ''Sesame Street.'' ''As high as a building?'' ''A hundred feet?'' guessed Craig Klein of Manhasset, L.I. ''We go straight up for 8 minutes,'' said Dr. Sally K. Ride, the astronaut, ''and after 2 minutes - by the time you could count to 20 - we're as high as the clouds.''

results.snippet: Politics always seems the most predictable of enterprises until something happens. That is when this city rediscovers, yet again, how quickly its conventional wisdom gets outdated.    The main attraction of the first week of the 1984 Presidential...
results.lead_paragraph: Politics always seems the most predictable of enterprises until something happens. That is when this city rediscovers, yet again, how quickly its conventional wisdom gets outdated. The main attraction of the first week of the 1984 Presidential campaign was supposed to be the sight of Walter F. Mondale lighting the fuse on his campaign rocket. Then came the Rev. Jesse Jackson's successful negotiation for the release of Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. In comparison, Mr. Mondale's liftoff seemed flat and uninspiring. He attained airspeed, but there was no sonic boom.

results.snippet: A Discoth eque Offers Its Glimpse of the Future    Inside a brick building amid TriBeCa   warehouses, a decontamination box with plump white eggs in it sits in the foyer. ''Danger! Respirators Required,'' a sign warns.

byline.original: By Susan Heller Anderson and Maurice Carroll

results.lead_paragraph: A Discoth eque Offers Its Glimpse of the Future Inside a brick building amid TriBeCa warehouses, a decontamination box with plump white eggs in it sits in the foyer. ''Danger! Respirators Required,'' a sign warns.

results.snippet: Q.   How is an adequate air supply maintained in spacecraft over long periods of time? How would oxygen be stored or manufactured in an orbiting space station?    A.Schemes envisioning the growing of algae or other plants in space to take up carbon...
results.lead_paragraph: Q. How is an adequate air supply maintained in spacecraft over long periods of time? How would oxygen be stored or manufactured in an orbiting space station? A.Schemes envisioning the growing of algae or other plants in space to take up carbon dioxide and produce oxygen have been imagined, according to Terry White, a spokesman for NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston, but for the foreseeable future air will continue to be supplied by carrying liquid oxygen in superinsulated Dewar containers (much like high-tech thermos bottles) at about minus 420 degrees Fahrenheit. Heavy high-pressure containers like those used for compressed oxygen by hospitals or industries are not required, so the six pounds or so of oxygen that an astronaut requires every day is no tremendous burden on the spacecraft's cargo capacity. A space station, Mr. White says, would periodically be resupplied with oxygen from earth, and even a 500-day Mars mission would probably get by with stored oxygen. Carbon dioxide breathed out by the astronauts would probably be disposed of as it is now, in lithium hydroxide scrubbers that absorb it from the cabin atmosphere.

headline.main: REAGAN AND CONGRESS ASSAILED ON PLIGHT OF BLACKS

results.snippet: The National Urban League charged today that the Reagan Administration and Congress were displaying a complaceny toward the plight of blacks and the economically deprived that bordered on ''the callous.''    Releasing its annual report on the...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Urban League charged today that the Reagan Administration and Congress were displaying a complaceny toward the plight of blacks and the economically deprived that bordered on ''the callous.'' Releasing its annual report on the ''State of Black America,'' the civil rights organization presented a bleak, strongly worded assessment in which it warned that poor blacks were being relegated to ''an out-of-sight, out- of-mind'' status in American life. ''The state of black America is disastrous,'' John E. Jacob, the league president, said in making the report public. ''While white Americans celebrate a long-overdue economic recovery and a falling unemployment rate, black America is buried in a depression of crushing proportions. The plain ugly fact is that there is no recovery for black Americans.''

headline.main: NUNN WON'T BACK GLENN ALL THE WAY

results.snippet: Senator Sam Nunn went to a rostrum at the State Capitol today and vigorously expressed his support for Senator John Glenn's drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination.     But Senator Nunn, regarded as the most popular political figure in...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator Sam Nunn went to a rostrum at the State Capitol today and vigorously expressed his support for Senator John Glenn's drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination. But Senator Nunn, regarded as the most popular political figure in Georgia, refused under repeated questioning, to say whether he would vote for Mr. Glenn in the Georgia primary. Officials in the Glenn campaign, which has been seeking Mr. Nunn's endorsement for a year, said that his remarks today were tantamount to endorsement.

headline.main: MCGOVERN AND HART GAIN GROUND WITH FARMERS

results.snippet: George McGovern and Gary Hart appeared today to have gained some ground among farmers who heard the views of six Democratic Presidential candidates at a forum on agricultural policy Saturday night.    Of the two, Mr. McGovern, the former Senator...
results.lead_paragraph: George McGovern and Gary Hart appeared today to have gained some ground among farmers who heard the views of six Democratic Presidential candidates at a forum on agricultural policy Saturday night. Of the two, Mr. McGovern, the former Senator from South Dakota, appeared to score the most points with the farmers, as both men promised to back sharp increases in farm income support programs and Mr. McGovern joined Walter F. Mondale and other candidates in evoking a fear that present national policies could lead to armed conflict. ''I went there favoring Mondale and I came away favoring McGovern,'' said Richard Myers, a farmer from the nearby village of Maxwell. ''For me it would be pretty close between McGovern and Hart,'' said James Milligan, who is from southern Illinois. ''I guess if I had to choose right now, I'd give the edge to McGovern.''

headline.main: A REPOTER'S NOTEBOOK: INTRODUCING AN ASTRONAUT

results.snippet: Introducing a man who, as those who are charged with doing it almost inevitably put it, needs no introduction can produce some problems of its own.    In Senator John Glenn's case, the speakers often start with Mr. Glenn's boyhood in New Concord,...
results.lead_paragraph: Introducing a man who, as those who are charged with doing it almost inevitably put it, needs no introduction can produce some problems of its own. In Senator John Glenn's case, the speakers often start with Mr. Glenn's boyhood in New Concord, Ohio, mention his war record and then skip to the Ohio Democrat's days in the space program and the flight that made him the first American to orbit the earth. Sometimes the people who introduce the candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination add a sprinkle too much of glamour. Usually it takes the form of describing him as the first American in space, who was Alan B. Shepard Jr. a year before Colonel Glenn climbed into his Mercury-Atlas rocket ship.

headline.main: THREE WHO ARE FIERCELY LOYAL TO REAGAN

results.snippet: There was a day when Louise DeBardeleben, a woman of old Alabama charm enjoying her ninth decade, came to the White House to visit her granddaughter, Margaret D. Tutwiler, one of the busier executives in Ronald Reagan's inner circle.   ''You look...
results.lead_paragraph: There was a day when Louise DeBardeleben, a woman of old Alabama charm enjoying her ninth decade, came to the White House to visit her granddaughter, Margaret D. Tutwiler, one of the busier executives in Ronald Reagan's inner circle. ''You look tired, dear,'' she said to Miss Tutwiler, a special assistant to the President and a workaholic who puts in 12-hour-plus days. ''You should go home and put your feet up.'' Margaret Tutwiler, who lately is engulfed with preparations for the 1984 Presidential campaign, still smiles at the dated charm of that prescription from a grand lady who never worked a day in her life.

results.snippet: There's one glaring fault with the manned space station the President proposed in his State of the Union speech: its striking lack of imagination or technological challenge.   Unlike President Kennedy's call to put man on the moon by 1970, a manned...
results.lead_paragraph: There's one glaring fault with the manned space station the President proposed in his State of the Union speech: its striking lack of imagination or technological challenge. Unlike President Kennedy's call to put man on the moon by 1970, a manned station would scarcely stretch present technology. Far from being among the ''giant steps for mankind,'' as Mr. Reagan suggested, it would be what his own science adviser called the proposal a year ago: a ''most unfortunate step backward.''

headline.main: SHUTTLE: TOUCH OF BUCK ROGERS PLANNED

results.snippet: ON the next space shuttle mission, scheduled to begin Friday, two astronauts will put on Buck Rogers-style jet backpacks and fly out from the Challenger. For several hours, free of any connection with the spaceship and with their own power to...
results.lead_paragraph: ON the next space shuttle mission, scheduled to begin Friday, two astronauts will put on Buck Rogers-style jet backpacks and fly out from the Challenger. For several hours, free of any connection with the spaceship and with their own power to maneuver, they will be in effect the first human satellites. They will be testing the new jet backpacks, known as manned maneuvering units, and rehearsing for future roles as orbital repairmen. At an altitude of 190 miles, traveling 17,400 miles an hour, they will practice techniques for approaching and hooking on to space objects, refueling satellites and replacing faulty satellite parts.
